items.explanation:
An algorithm is like a recipe - a step-by-step set of instructions to solve a problem. Just like a recipe tells you how to make a cake, an algorithm tells a computer how to solve a problem.

Example: Finding the largest number in a list
1. Start with the first number as your 'current largest'
2. Look at each remaining number
3. If you find a bigger number, make it your new 'current largest'
4. When you've checked all numbers, you have the answer!

This same pattern works whether you have 10 numbers or 10 million numbers.
items.real_world_connection: This is exactly how sports tournaments work - you keep track of the 'current champion' and see if anyone can beat them!

items.explanation:
Imagine two friends sorting a deck of cards:

Alice uses 'Selection Sort': She finds the smallest card and puts it first, then finds the next smallest, and so on.

Bob uses 'Bubble Sort': He goes through the deck repeatedly, swapping adjacent cards if they're in the wrong order.

Let's see what happens as the deck gets bigger!

items.intuitive_explanation: Imagine you're organizing a line of people by height, but you can only swap adjacent people. The tallest person will 'bubble up' to the end by swapping with each shorter person they encounter.

items.prompt: Merge Sort: The Divide and Conquer Champion
items.big_picture: What if instead of sorting 1000 items, you sorted two groups of 500 items and then merged them? And what if you sorted those 500-item groups by sorting 250-item groups and merging? This 'divide and conquer' approach is incredibly powerful!

intuitive_explanation.scenario: Organizing Two Sorted Piles of Papers
intuitive_explanation.setup: You have two stacks of papers, each already sorted by date. How do you combine them into one sorted stack?
intuitive_explanation.strategy: Look at the top paper of each stack. Take whichever has the earlier date and put it in your final pile. Repeat until both stacks are empty.
intuitive_explanation.insight: Merging two sorted lists is much easier than sorting from scratch!

step1.title: The Merge Function
step1.description: First, let's build the function that merges two sorted arrays
step1.code:
def merge(left, right):
    result = []
    i = j = 0
    
    # Compare elements from both arrays
    while i < len(left) and j < len(right):
        if left[i] <= right[j]:
            result.append(left[i])
            i += 1
        else:
            result.append(right[j])
            j += 1
    
    # Add remaining elements
    result.extend(left[i:])
    result.extend(right[j:])
    return result

items.prompt: Quick Sort: The Clever Partitioning Trick
items.motivation: What if we could sort without fully sorting? Quick Sort uses a clever trick: pick an element (called a 'pivot') and arrange all smaller elements to its left and larger elements to its right. Now the pivot is in its final position! Repeat this process on the left and right sides.

partition_demo.process: Move all elements < 6 to the left, all elements > 6 to the right
partition_demo.insight: Now 6 is in its final sorted position! We just need to sort the left and right parts.

implementation.quicksort_function:
def quicksort(arr, low, high):
    if low < high:
        # Partition and get pivot index
        pi = partition(arr, low, high)
        
        # Recursively sort elements before and after partition
        quicksort(arr, low, pi - 1)
        quicksort(arr, pi + 1, high)

items.intuitive_introduction: Big-O notation is like predicting how your workload scales. If you're organizing 10 books, the method doesn't matter much. But if you're organizing 10,000 books, the method makes a huge difference!

O(1).name: Constant Time
O(1).analogy: Looking up a word in a dictionary when someone gives you the exact page number
O(1).scaling: Same time regardless of input size

O(log n).name: Logarithmic Time
O(log n).analogy: Finding a word in a dictionary using the divide-and-eliminate strategy
O(log n).scaling: Doubles the input, adds one more step

O(n).name: Linear Time
O(n).analogy: Reading every page of a book to find a specific sentence
O(n).scaling: Double the input, double the time

O(n log n).name: Linearithmic Time
O(n log n).analogy: Organizing books by first grouping by topic (n work) then sorting each group (log n work)

O(nÂ²).name: Quadratic Time
O(nÂ²).analogy: Comparing every book with every other book to find duplicates
O(nÂ²).scaling: Double the input, quadruple the time
